pullRequest.title: Add ability to answer cards via javascript in WebView

nodes.bodyText:
This logic branch ("are we showing the answer? if not show the answer...") is duplicated 4 times, seems it could be pulled up into one if(url.contains("signal:answer_ease")) { if (!sDisplayAnswer) { displayCardAnswer(); return true; } then a switch on which answer_easeN was requested?
Also please note that your whitespace is inconsistent, we use a space after if, before parentheses - 'if (' not 'if('
likewise, we have a space between close parentheses and open curly brace - ') {' vs '){'

A pervasive issue is the naming of EASE_X in AbstractFlashCardViewer. This refers to the ordinal of the button, not the answer. This is better due to the V2 Scheduler adding "Hard", but there are still some cases where these don't match.
It'd be good to either document this assumption heavily, or do away with it and move to a "Hard/Good/Easy" based approach.

  
    
      Anki-Android/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/AbstractFlashcardViewer.java
    
    
        Lines 1251 to 1255
      in
      86ef26c
    
    
    
    

        
          
           case EASE_2: 
        

        
          
               mChosenAnswer.setText("\u2022\u2022"); 
        

        
          
               mChosenAnswer.setTextColor(ContextCompat.getColor(this, buttonNumber == 4 ? 
        

        
          
                       R.color.material_blue_grey_600: 
        

        
          
                       R.color.material_green_500)); 
        
    
  


I have the code to do this on my PC (ping for a copy if we want to go down this route).

I don't think we provide the user with a method of obtaining the available number of buttons (or an array of the buttons themselves), but we should consider adding this since we don't yet have a mechanism to return data from a signal.
Also have something close to this logic sitting on my PC.
Current implementation of providing data to a card from Android:
